events.title: Sack of Rome by the Visigoths
events.description: The Visigoths led by King Alaric I sacked Rome, marking the first time in 800 years that the city had been captured by a foreign enemy, signaling the decline of the Western Roman Empire.
events.significance: This event symbolized the weakening of Roman power and the transition to the Middle Ages in Europe.

events.title: Eruption of Mount Vesuvius
events.description: Mount Vesuvius erupted catastrophically, burying the Roman cities of Pompeii and Herculaneum under volcanic ash and preserving them for centuries.
events.significance: The eruption provides critical archaeological insights into Roman life and has influenced volcanology and disaster preparedness.

events.title: Burning of Washington during the War of 1812
events.description: British forces invaded Washington, D.C., setting fire to the White House, the Capitol, and other public buildings during the War of 1812.
events.significance: This event was a major blow to American morale but galvanized national resolve during the young nation's conflict with Britain.

events.title: Audi brand founded
events.description: August Horch founded the Audi brand, which would go on to become one of the leading luxury automobile manufacturers in the world.
events.significance: This marked the beginning of a brand that would be influential in automotive engineering and design.

events.title: North Atlantic Treaty signed
events.description: The North Atlantic Treaty was signed in Washington, D.C., establishing NATO as a military alliance among Western nations.
events.significance: NATO was a key organization in the Cold War, providing collective security against Soviet expansion.
